message.content:
In mathematics, there are many methods to multiply two numbers or values. Some of these include:
Traditional multiplication

1. Long multiplication: This is the classic method taught in schools where you multiply each digit of one number with each digit of another, then carry and add to get the final product.

2. Lattice multiplication (also known as gelosia): a method involving drawing a lattice/grid where rows represent digits from one number while columns represent digits from another; you then fill in products and diagonals for addition.

3. Russian Peasant algorithm: this involves halving the first number until it becomes 1 while doubling the second number simultaneously; finally, odd whole-number results from the first sequence are added up along with corresponding multiples of the second sequence.

Array Models/Box Method:

4. Box/array-method: Divide both factors into their basic components (e.g., tens or ones), create an array using those components multiplied together entered into squares within boxes created through intersecting lines yielding partial products - which when totaled equals answer.

5. Area model/multiplication using base ten blocks: A geometric method to show why multiplicands work by visually showing place value relationships via regions called "base-ten-pieces". As such, students physically manipulate them gaining understanding on how areas grow providing better comprehension leading towards abstraction concepts thereafter (i.e., doing mental arithmetic without needing visual models.)

Alternative Methods:

6. Napier's bones/by logarithms tables/checking-circles/lists-rules/method originated by priest John Napier simplifying computation huge amounts multiplying-digits written down replicated tapered rulers/strips thereby leading users to answers functioning today analogous electronic computers/calculators process complex data/mathematics/formulas aiding scientific reasoning workflow-effectiveness/engineering/manufacturing
